File.Title: Crossed Connections of the Substantia Nigra in the Rat
File.Authors: CHARLES R. GERFEN, WILLIAM A. STAINES, GORDON W. ARBUTHNOTT, AND HANS C. FIBIGER

Abstract.S: The existence of crossed multisynaptic pathways that allow for the interdependent control of activity in one substantia nigra and its contralateral counterpart has been inferred from a number of recent biochemical and neurophysiological investigations.
This prompted a reexamination of the connections of the substantia nigra with an emphasis on crossed inputs to and crossed projections from that nucleus.

Male albino rats received 2050-nl pressure injections of a 1% wheat germ agglutinin-conjugated horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP) solution into the substantia nigra or into surrounding areas as controls.
Following a 24-hour survival period the animals were processed according to the tetramethylbenzidine protocol for the visualization of HRP.

The pattern of anterograde transport of WGA-HRP after substantia nigra injections, confirming for the most part previous reports, demonstrated ipsilateral nigral efferent projections to the striatum; globus pallidus; subthalamic nucleus; the lateral dorsal, paralamellar mediodorsal, ventromedial, and parafascicular thalamic nuclei; central gray, midbrain reticular formation; superior colliculus; and peribrachial area, including the pedunculopontine nucleus.
Additionally, the nigral projections to the paralamellar mediodorsal and ventromedial thalamic nuclei and to the superior colliculus were demonstrated to be bilateral.
Most of these connections were confirmed by the complementary retrograde experiment.

In accordance with previous reports, intranigral WGA-HRP injections retrogradely labeled neurons located in the ipsilateral prefrontal cortex, motor cortex, striatum, globus pallidus, central nucleus of the amygdala, anterior hypothalamic area, subthalamic nucleus, and dorsal raphe.

Additionally, labeled perikarya were observed in the ipsilateral parafascicular thalamic nucleus, in the contralateral posterior lateral hypothalamic area, and in the ipsilateral and contralateral peribrachial-pedunculopontine area.
These latter nigral afferents were confirmed with complementary WGA-HRP injections into each of the regions of origin.

While bilateral peribrachial-pedunculopontine innervation of the substantia nigra has been reported in the cat there has been no previous demonstration of a crossed nigral afferent system from the contralateral posterior lateral hypothalamic area.
The results are discussed with reference to the pathways that may mediate the interdependent control of the activity of neurons in the left and right substantia nigra.

Additionally, the association of the substantia nigra with a variety of neuronal circuits, including the cerebellofugal, tectothalamic, thalamocortical, thalamostriatal, and basal ganglia pathways, are discussed.

Introduction.S: Gerfen, Developmental Neurobiology Laboratory, The Salk Institute, P.O.

Box 85800, San Diego, CA Recent biochemical and electrophysiological investigations are suggestive of crossed connections that allow for the interdependent control of activity in the left and right substantia nigra (Cheramy et al., '81).

Although there is no evidence of a direct connection between one substantia nigra and its contralateral counterpart, unilateral application of glycine or GABA-related compounds to the substantia nigra results in symmetric changes in the activity of both nigrostriatal dopamine (DA) pathways (Leviel et al., '79).

Also, asymmetric changes occur in the activity of the two nigrostriatal pathways after unilateral sensory stimulation (Nieoullon et al., '77b) or after unilateral modification of DA transmission within the substantia nigra (Leviel et al., '79; Nieoullon et al., '77a).
These data point to the existence of one or more crossed, presumably multisynaptic connections, linking activity in the two structures.

To date anterograde tracing techniques have revealed partly crossed efferent connections of the substantia nigra that include the innervation of the paralamellar portion of the mediodorsal thalamic nucleus, the central gray region that includes the dorsal raphe, and the lateral dorsal tegmental nucleus (Beckstead et al., '79).

Additionally, retrograde transport studies have suggested a minor contralateral projection to the ventromedial nucleus of the thalamus from the substantia nigra (Herkenham, '79) and there is electrophysiological evidence for a crossed nigrotectal projection (Deniau et al., '77).

In the present study confirmation of these pathways was obtained and additional crossed nigral connections were revealed using the tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) method (Mesulam, '78) for the visualization of axonally transported wheat germ agglutinin-conjugated horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP) (Staines et al., '80).

These new connections include nigral afferents from a restricted region of the contralateral posterior lateral hypothalamic area and from the ipsilateral and contralateral peribrachial area including the pedunculopontine nucleus.
Additionally, the existence of a nigral efferent pathway to the ipsilateral lateral dorsal thalamic nucleus was demonstrated.

Methods.S: Male albino rats, anesthetized with pentobarbital, received 20-50-nl pressure injections of a 1% WGA-HRP solution into the substantia nigra.
Injections were made from a 1-pl Hamilton syringe fitted with a 31-gauge cannula.
The cannula was inserted stereotaxically by using a 45" approach.

After a 24-hour survival period the animals were reanesthetized and perfused sequentially with 50 ml of a 0.9% saline solution containing 0.25% procaine and 0.001% heparin at room temperature, 400 ml of 1.0% formaldehyde and 1.25% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) at room temperature, and 250 ml of an ice-cold 10% sucrose solution in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).
The brains were removed and placed in 10% sucrose phosphate at 5" C until sectioned.

Frozen sections (50 pm) were cut and mounted from 0.1 M phosphate b&er (pH 7.4) onto chrome-alum-coated slides, dried under a stream of cool air, and reacted according to the TMB method of Mesulam ('78).
The sections were coverslipped without counterstaining and examined under darkfield illumination.
Control injections of WGA-HRP were made along the angled approach to the substantia nigra and into the regions rostral, caudal and dorsal to that nucleus.
Additional WGA-HRP injections were made into the parafascicular thalamic nucleus and the peribrachial area.

Iontophoretic WGA-HRP injections were made into various brain regions through a micropipette (10-20-pm tip diameter) filled with a 1% WGA-HRP solution in 0.9% saline using a 2 pamp positive current for 5 minutes.
Iontophoretic injections of WGA-HRP were made into the posterior lateral hypothalamic area; superior colliculus; and laterodorsal, mediodorsal, and parafascicular thalamic nuclei.
Histochemical controls were run by processing animals which had not received tracer injections.

Results.S: RESULTS
Technical considerations
Although the TMB reaction affords a highly sensitive visualization of the HRP marker there are a number of technical considerations that must be addressed.
First, it is not possible to determine the exact area in and around an injection site from which neuronal elements may take up and transport demonstrable amounts of the enzyme.

Possible spread of the enzyme along the injection tract further complicates the delineation of the injection area, as does the observation that the apparent injection site is smaller at 24 hours' survival than at shorter time intervals (Kim and Strick, '76; Staines et al., '80).
For these reasons , the pattern of WGA - HRP transport following injections into the substantia nigra was compared to those observed fallawing various control injections .
Outlines of these control injections are shown in Figure 3.
Second, evidence was obtained in the present study that WGA-HRP, like HRP, may be taken up and transported by damaged fibers or by fibers of passage (Herkenham and Nauta, '77).
This problem was also addressed by comparison of the labeling seen after injections into the substantia nigra with that obtained after control injections.
In instances where such comparisons were not conclusive , complementary WGA - HRP injections were made into areas suggested to be connected with the substantia nigra .
Hence , nigral efferent and afferent projections were confirmed by the presence of perikaryal and terminal labeling respectively in the substantia nigra after WGA - HRP injections into target areas .

In all cases the criterion used to determine a WGA - HRPlabeled terminal field was the presence of labeled fibers to and within an area in which a moderately dense punctate distribution of reaction product was evident .

Labeled perikarya in an area of presumed terminal labeling somewhat compromised this analysis because of the possibility that all or part of the extraperikaryal peroxidase activity was localized in labeled dendrites or efferent rather than afferent axons and terminals .
In these cases , WGA - HRP was injected into the presumed terminal regions to establish the presence or absence of retrograde transport to substantia nigra neurons .
Nigral injections

TTE.S: Anterograde and retrograde labeling of neuronal elements resulting from an injection of WGA - HRP apparently confined to the substantia nigra are shown in Figure 2.

The injection was centered in the pars reticulata and led to dense labeling of neurons , presumably by direct soma1 or dendritic uptake , around the injection center in the pars reticulata and pars cornpacta .

That the injection did not spread into the medially adjacent ventral tegmental area can be inferred by the absence of labeling of neurons in the ventral tegmental area and by the absence of anterograde transport to the nucleus accumbens , known to receive a massive input from that area ( Beckstead et al . , ' 79 ) .
In the case depicted , there was negligible diffusion of WGA - HRP along the injection tract .
There was no evidence that the tracer had spread into the cerebral peduncle ventral to the substantia nigra .
Retrograde labeling .
The retrograde labeling in this case confirms previous findings in the rat ( Hattori et al . , ' 75 ; Bunney and Aghajanian , ' 76 ; Van Der Kooy and Hattori , ' 80 ) .

These include ipsilateral inputs from the dorsal agranular insular prefrontal cortex ( A18 ( terminology of Krettek and Price , ' 77 ; after Rose , ' 28 ) , medial and lateral precentral cortex , striatum , globus pallidus , subthalamic nucleus , dorsal raphe and minor ipsilateral inputs from the hypothalamus , central nucleus of the amygdala, and lateral habenula .
In addition , three other brain regions contain retrogradely labeled neurons .

These include the contralateral posterior lateral hypothalamic area , the ipsilateral parafascicular thalamic nucleus , and the ipsilatera1 and contralateral peribrachial region including the pedunculopontine nucleus .
Anterograde transport.

Terminal labeling was identified in the following brain regions : ( 1 ) the ipsilateral striatum ; ( 2 ) ipsilateral globus pallidus ; ( 3 ) thalamic nuclei including the ipsilateral lateral dorsal nucleus , ipsilateral and contralateral paralamellar portion of the mediodorsal nucleus , the ipsilateral ventromedial nucleus in its entirety , the dorsal portion of the contralateral ventromedial nucleus , and the ipsilateral parafascicular nucleus ; ( 4 ) ipsilateral subthalamic nucleus ; ( 5 ) a discrete region of the rostral midbrain ventromedial to the medial longitudinal fasciculus ; ( 6 ) the ipsilateral dorsal midbrain tegmentum ; ( 7 ) the ipsilateral and contralateral superior colliculus ; ( 8 ) the central gray region , bilaterally ; and ( 9 ) the ipsilateral peribrachial - pedunculopontine area ( see Fig . 2 ) .
Nigral afferents from the contralateral hypothalamus .
Peroxidase - labeled neurons located in the contralateral posterior lateral hypothalamus were confined to a discrete area just lateral to the mammillothalamic tract ( Figs . 2F , G , 4, 6 ) .
The largest nigral WGA - HRP injection labeled a total of 120 of these neurons .
Only WGA - HRP injections into the rostral half of the substantia nigra labeled these cells .

To investigate the possibility that these neurons were labeled by uptake into fibers of passage running through the substantia nigra or by uptake of tracer that had spread outside the confines of the substantia nigra , despite the fact that the latter was not apparent , the control injections outlined in Figure 3 were made .

Results.S: Hypothalamic neurons labeled after control injections.
Figure 4 shows a composite map of the location of hypothalamic neurons labeled after the control WGA - HRP injections outlined in Figure 3.
The locations of posterior lateral hypothalamic neurons labeled after contralateral nigral injections are indicated by stars in Figure 4 for comparison .
As is evident in Figure 4 the great majority of hypothalamic neurons labeled after control injections were not located in the contralateral posterior lateral hypothalamus .
Two cases warrant further comment.
First, supramammillary neurons have been reported to project bilaterally to the dentate gyrus (Pasquier and Reinoso-Suarez, '76; Wyss et al., '79), hence their labeling by injection c-t.
However , labeled supramammillary neurons occupied a position ventromedial to the neurons labeled after injections into the substantia nigra .
Second , posterior lateral hypothalamic neurons were labeled contralateral to control injections into the dorsal midbrain tegmentum .
Although comparable in size to nigral injections , control injections labeled only three to four posterior lateral hypothalamic neurons as opposed to the 120 labeled by nigral injections .
Lateral hypothalamic injections

TTE.S: The pattern of labeling resulting from an iontophoretic injection of WGA - HRP into the lateral hypothalamus is shown in Figure 5.

The injection spread between the cerebral peduncle and the mammillothalamic tract from the level of the subthalamic nucleus to the rostral part of the ventral tegmental area and included the medial zona incerta and medial edge of the cerebral peduncle .
Crossed posterior lateral hypothalamonigral pathway.
Numerous labeled fibers crossed in the supramammillary decussation and progressed laterally and caudally into the substantia nigra pars compacta and pars reticulata .
Labeled fibers in the pars compacta were observed with collaterals which descended into the pars reticulata ( Fig . 6 0 .
Numerous fibers were observed within the pars reticulata within an area of moderately dense terminallike labeling ( Figs . 5D - F , 6D ) .
This pattern of transport was most evident in the rostral and particularly lateral part of the substantia nigra and became progressively less apparent in more caudal sections .
Labeled fibers were infrequently observed lateral or caudal to the substantia nigra indicating that once fibers entered the substantia nigra only rarely did they exit from that nucleus .
Failure to label neurons in the contralateral posterior lateral hypothalamus after control injections caudal or lateral to the substantia nigra is consistent with this conclusion .
Ipsiluteral nigral labeling after hypothalamic injections.
Injections into the lateral hypothalamus labeled perikarya in the ipsilateral ventral tegmental area and substantia nigra pars compacta .
The substantia nigra pars reticulata contained a moderate , homogeneous distribution of terminal - like labeling throughout its rostrocaudal extent .

It would be difficult to attribute the origin of this nigral terminal labeling to perikarya within the hypothalamic injection area since no perikarya were labeled within this area after nigral WGA - HRP injections .

The corticonigral and striatonigral pathways course through the cerebral peduncle and the lateral hypothalamus in the former case ( Leonard , ' 69 ; Beckstead , ' 79 ) and through the cerebral peduncle in the latter case ( Nagy et al . , ' 78 ) before terminating in the substantia nigra pars reticulata .
Uptake by fibers of these pathways may account for labeling in the ipsilateral substantia nigra .
Labeling of neurons in the pars compacta may have been due to uptake by fibers of passage of the nigrostriatal bundle .
Alternatively , the possibility is raised that the tracer was taken up through boutons en passant of nigrostriatal fibers in the posterior lateral hypothalamic area .
Extranigral labeling after hypothalamic injections.
Labeled fibers were observed ascending into the dorsal midbrain tegmentum ( both ipsilateral and contralateral to hypothalamic injections ) .
These fibers followed a course medial to, through, or lateral to the medial leminscus.
Labeled terminals were more abundant in the ipsilateral midbrain tegmentum .
Neurons that contribute to this labeling are most likely located in the zona incerta and lateral hypothalamic areas within the injection site ( Fig . 4 ) .
For the most part these areas are distinct from the posterior lateral hypothalamic area from which the crossed hypothalamonigral projection originates .
However, a small number of perikarya within this area are labeled contralateral to dorsal midbrain tegmentum WGAHRP injections (Fig. 4F).
It is possible that neurons in the posterior lateral hypothalamus give rise to branched efferents to the dorsal midbrain tegmentum and substantia nigra .

Results.S: The entopeduncular , peribrachial - pedunculopontine , and lateral dorsal tegmental nuclei , in which labeled perikarya were observed after lateral hypothalamic injections , have been reported to project to the lateral hypothalamus ( Tohyama et al . , ' 78 ; Nauta , ' 79 ; Moon - Edley and Graybiel , ' 80 ) .

However , the possible contribution of uptake and transport of peroxidase by fibers of passage ( Herkenham and Nauta , ' 77 ) to the pattern of labeling after these iontophoretic injections must be taken into consideration .

Pathways which pass through the injection site , and are thus possibly involved , include the descending projections from the nucleus accumbens into the midbrain ( Nauta et al . , ' 78 ) and the reciprocal connections between the entopeduncular nucleus and the peribrachial - pedunculopontine area ( Nauta , ' 79 ) .
Nigral connections with the peribrachialpedunculopontine area

TTE.S: Substantia nigra WGA - HRP injections labeled neurons in the peribrachial - pedunculopontine area , bilaterally .

While it is not possible to identify anterograde labeling with certainty when retrograde labeling is present in the same area , there also appeared to be terminal labeling of the ipsilateral but not contralateral area ( see Figs . 2K , L , 7 ) .
Injections of WGA - HRP into the peribrachial - pedunculopontine area resulted in labeling of perikarya in the ipsilateral but not contralateral substantia nigra pars reticulata .

Additionally , these injections resulted in apparent labeling of terminals in the substantia nigra and the subthalamic nucleus , bilaterally , as well as labeling of perikarya in the entopeduncular nucleus and hypothalamus .
Injections of WGA - HRP into the subthalamic nucleus resulted in the bilateral labeling of perikarya in the periNigrothalamic connections
Parafascicular nucleus.
Injections of WGA - HRP into the substantia nigra labeled a few neurons in the ipsilateral parafascicular nucleus ( Fig . 2F ) and apparently labeled terminals in the same area ( Fig . 8A ) .
Injections into the parafascicular nucleus labeled in excess of 100 perikarya in the ipsilateral substantia nigra pars reticulata ( Fig . 8B , E ) , located primarily in its most medial extent .
A few neurons were labeled in the contralateral subthalamic nucleus .

Terminal labeling was seen in the ipsilateral substantia nigra pars reticulata , striatum , subthalamic nucleus , and interpeduncular nucleus , and labeled perikarya were found bilaterally in the entopeduncular nucleus , hypothalamus , superior colliculus , and peribrachial - pedunculopontine area , and ipsilaterally in the lateral habenula and lateral dorsal tegmental nucleus .
Previous studies have identified all of these connections with the exception of those implied by the labeling of the lateral habenula and interpeduncular nucleus ( Ahlenius , ' 78 ) .

As the tip of the injection cannula was located in the fasciculus retroflexus peroxidase labeling of these latter two areas probably represents transport of the tracer by intact or damaged fibers of passage.
Of particular significance was the heterogeneous pattern of terminal labeling in the striatum after injections into the parafascicular nucleus ( Fig . 8D ) .

Results.S: Ventromedial thalamic nucleus .

TTE.S: Injections of WGA - HRP into the substantia nigra resulted in dense terminal and fiber labeling in the ipsilateral ventromedial thalamic nucleus ( Fig . 9 ) .
Additionally , there was evidence of a sparse distribution of labeled terminals in the most dorsal portion of the contralateral ventromedial nucleus ( Fig . 2D , E , 9 ) .
Mediodorsal thalamic nucleus .
There was distinctive bilateral labeling of terminals in the paralamellar portion of the mediodorsal thalamic nucleus after WGA - HRP injections into the substantia nigra ( Figs . 2D , E , 9 ) .
Fibers appeared to enter the mediodorsal nuclei through the intralaminar nuclei .
It was not possible to determine whether labeling within the intralaminar nuclei was due to the presence of peroxidase in preterminal axons or whether there were labeled terminals as well .
Iontophoretic injections of WGA - HRP were made into the mediodorsal thalamic nucleus and included the central lateral intralaminar thalamic nucleus .

One injection site was centered in the central and most ventral portion of the mediodorsal nucleus and included the central portion of the paralamellar portion of the nucleus ( Fig . 10, Case MD - M ) .
There was little detectable spread of the tracer into the intralaminar nuclei .
In excess of 400 labeled perikarya were observed in the ipsilateral substantia nigra pars reticulata , located primarily in the ventral part of the nucleus throughout its rostrocaudal extent .

In excess of 80 labeled perikarya were observed in each of the following brain areas : ( 1 ) the contralateral posterior lateral hypothalamic area ; ( 2 ) the AId prefrontal cortex , bilaterally and the ipsilateral ventral agranular insular cortex ( AIv ) , ( 3 ) the medial precentral cortex , bilaterally ; ( 4 ) the magnocellular nuclei of the basal forebrain , bilaterally ; ( 5 ) the ipsilateral reticular thalamic nucleus ; ( 6 ) the ipsilateral nucleus of the posterior commissure ; ( 7 ) the superior colliculus, bilaterally ; ( 8 ) the dorsal midbrain tegmentum bilaterally ; ( 9 ) the peribrachial - peduncdopontine area , bilaterally ; and ( 10 ) the dorsal lateral tegmental nucleus, bilaterally .
These findings are inclusive of those given in a recent report ( Sapawi and Divac , ' 78 ) .
Labeled neurons in the contralateral posterior lateral hypothalamic area were localized to the same area as those labeled after injections into the substantia nigra .
Collicular neurons were distributed bilaterally in the central portion of the intermediate and deep layers .
A second injection into the mediodorsal nucleus labeled an area slightly lateral to that described above and included the central lateral intralaminar nucleus ( Fig . 10, Case MD - L ) .
The retrograde labeling resulting from this second caae generally conformed with that described for the first case.
Several differences were, however, noteworthy.
First , only perikarya in the ipsilateral and contralateral AId prefrontal cortex were labeled , not those in the AIv prefrontal cortex .
The medial precentral cortex and the medial aspect of the lateral precentral cortex contained labeled perikarya , bilaterally .
Second , labeled collicular perikarya were situated in the most lateral aspect of the intermediate and deep layers , bilaterally , rather than in the central portion ( Fig . 10 ) .

Third , while the number of labeled perikarya in the ipsilateral substantia nigra pars reticulata was roughly equivalent to those labeled after the more central injection , the more lateral injection into the mediodorsal nucleus labeled perikarya in the dorsal pars reticulata .
This same relationship was evident in the contralateral substantia nigra .

Results.S: These findings are depicted in Figure 10.

TTE.S: An injection into the central lateral intralaminar thalamic nucleus which included the most medial edge of the ventrolateral nucleus labeled very few perikarya in the substantia nigra and the most lateral aspect of the intermediate and deep layers of the superior colliculus .

Results.S: Lateral dorsal thulamic nucleus .

TTE.S: After WGA - HRP injections into the substania nigra , fibers were observed passing through the intralaminar nuclei in a laterodorsal direction .
These fibers continued to the lateral dorsal thalamic nucleus within which a sparse terminal - like distribution of label was apparent ( Figs . 2, 9 ) .
A similar, although more sparse pattern, was evident contralateral to the injection.
To test the suggestion that this area receives nigral efferents , WGA - HRP was applied iontophoretically into the laterodorsal thalamic nucleus .
The injection site appeared to be confined to this nucleus with minimal spread to the adjacent intralaminar complex ( Fig . 8C ) .
In excess of 50 labeled perikarya were observed in the ipsilateral substantia nigra pars reticulata ( Fig . 8F ) .
These neurons were located in the most ventral part of that nucleus immediately adjacent to the cerebral peduncle .
Labeled perikarya were not observed in the contralateral substantia nigra .

Additionally , labeled perikarya were observed bilaterally in the pretectal nuclei , the lateral dorsal tegmental nuclei , and in ipsilateral brain regions including the zona incerta , lateral hypothalamus , and nucleus cuneiformis .

Results.S: Nigrotectal connections

TTE.S: Following WGA - HRP injections into the substantia nigra labeled fibers were observed that exited from the lateral aspect of the nucleus and then curved medially into the dorsal midbrain tegmentum where characteristic terminal labeling was apparent .
Two sets of fibers were seen to continue , one medially into the central gray and another dorsally and laterally into the superior colliculus .

In coronal section the intermediate tectal layer stratum album intermediale , which is interposed between the stratum griseum intermediale above and the stratum griseum profundum below , is widest , in its dorsoventral dimension , in the most lateral part of the tectum and tapers toward the medial edge of the tectum .
Ipsilateral nigrotectal terminal labeling occupied the full extent of the stratum album intermediale .

In addition , in the lateral tectum the most dorsal portion of the stratum griseum profundum and , throughout its lateromedial extent , the ventral portion of the stratum griseum intermediale were included in the terminally labeled area .
This pattern was evident throughout the rostrocaudal extent of the superior colliculus .

The pufflike distribution of terminal labeling in this pathway , evident at low magnification , can , to some extent , be attributable to the absence of label in the bunched fiber fascicles interspersed within this layer .
As these fascicles are more dispersed in the lateral edge of the tectum , terminal labeling in this region is more homogenous ( Fig .
Numerous labeled fibers looped rostrally through the superior collicular decussation to terminate in the contralateral tectum ( Figs . 1, 2 H J , 11 ) .
In contrast to the distribution of terminals in the ipsilateral superior colliculus , that in the contralateral structure was restricted to the lateral part of the stratum griseum profundum .
For the most part this labeling was homogeneous except for the slight inclusion of the ventral aspect of the stratum album intermediale in the area containing terminals .

In the rostral tectum the lateral half of the deep layer contained labeled terminals , this area being restricted laterally in progressively more caudal sections and absent altogether in the caudal third of the tectum .

Results.S: The lateral portion of the superior colliculus has been considered by some to be a part of the dorsal midbrain tegmentum (Veazey and Severin, '80).

However, on the basis of its morphologic continuity with the intermediate and deep layers of the superior colliculus (Tokunga and Otani, '76) and the observation that it has been shown to contain cells of origin of the tectospinal pathway (Abrahams and Rose, '75) this lateral continuation is considered by others to be part of the superior colliculus.

The continuity of anterograde labeling after nigral injections and of retrograde labeling after injections into the mediodorsal nucleus of the thalamus ( see below ) provide further evidence that the area in question should be considered part of the superior colliculus .

TTE.S: Tectal WGA - HRP injections .
Iontophoretic applications of WGA - HRP were made into either the rostral or caudal halves of the superior colliculus .
Both injections deposited tracer into the intermediate and deep layers of the lateral tectum and into the most dorsal aspect of the dorsal midbrain tegmentum .
These injections resulted in distinctly different patterns of retrograde labeling in the substantia nigra pars reticulata ( Figs . 12,131.
The caudal injection labeled a large number of neurons in the rostral half of the ipsilateral pars reticulata confined primarily to a ventral area just above the cerebral peduncle .
Only two neurons were labeled in the contralateral substantia nigra .
The rostral injection labeled an even greater number of neurons in the ipsilateral substantia nigra pars reticulata .
Again these neurons were located in the rostral half of the nucleus ; however , in this case labeled perikarya were located in the dorsal three - fourths of the nucleus .

The contralateral substantia nigra pars reticulata contained in excess of 200 labeled perikarya , fewer than on the ipsilateral side , primarily confined to the rostral and dorsal portion of that nucleus .

The possible inclusion of the dorsal midbrain tegmentum in the injection area precludes a strict identification of all neurons labeled after these injections as exclusively part of the nigrotectal pathway.

However , control injections into the dorsal midbrain tegmentum , which did not include the lateral tectal area , labeled a relatively small number of ipsilateral and no contralateral perikarya in the substantia nigra pars reticulata .
Injections into the rostral superior colliculus resulted in terminal labeling in the paralamellar mediodorsal , parafascicular , and ventromedial thalamic nuclei .

Conversely , as described above , injections into the mediodorsal nucleus labeled perikarya in the intermediate and deep layers of the superior colliculus , the medial injection labeling perikarya in the medial superior colliculus and the lateral injection labeling perikarya in the lateral superior colliculus .
This mediolateral topography of neurons in the superior colliculus extended into the lateroventral aspect of the intermediate and deep layers .

Results.S: Injections into the mediodorsal nucleus also labeled perikarya in the dorsal midbrain tegmentum that were located ventral to those in the intermediate and deep tectal layers and did not appear to be part of the same topographic arrangement ( Fig . 10 ) .

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
It is now well established that HRP is taken up by neuronal somata and transported to nerve terminals in amounta that can be visualized with the TMB method.

The study of efferent connections using peroxidase is more convenient than radioamino acid techniques but the results must be interpreted with a greater measure of caution because of the possibility of fiber of passage artefacts (Walberg et al., '80).
The technique allows rapid confirmation of efferent connections by the complementary retrograde experiment, as has been done in many instances in the present study.
In this report the designation of areas as containing anterogradely labeled terminals is made with some confidence although this will have to be verified by electron microscopy.
The pattern of anterograde transport seen in the present study is in full accord with similar experiments using autoradiographic techniques (G.W.
Arbuthnott and A.
Wright, personal communication).
Hypothalamonigral connections

Perhaps most notable among the present findings was the demonstration of a crossed input to the substantia nigra from a discrete area of the posterior lateral hypothalamus, Retrograde transport of WGA-HRP following injections into the substantia nigra labeled as many as 120 neurons in the contralateral posterior lateral hypothalamus.
In the complementary experiment injections into the posterior lateral hypothalamus labeled fibers that appeared to terminate in the contralateral substantia nigra pars reticulata.
This crossed hypothalamic input was restricted to the rostral substantia nigra.

Additional significance is attributed to this finding in light of the observation that neurons in this same area of the posterior lateral hypothalamus project to the contralateral paralamellar mediodorsal thalamic nucleus, which itself receives nigral input.

Preliminary findings in retrograde double-labeling experiments indicate that neurons in the posterior lateral hypothalamus send collateral branches to both the contralateral substantia nigra pars reticulata and the contralateral mediodorsal thalamic nucleus (Gerfen and Staines, unpublished observations).

The crossed nigral afferents from the posterior lateral hypothalamus could participate in the reciprocal control of activity in one substantia nigra and its contralateral counterpart if it were demonstrated that this area receives afferents from the ipsilateral substantia nigra.
As the ipsilateral nigrostriatal pathway passes through the region in question (Fig. 6B) it would be of interest to determine whether the dopaminergic fibers have boutons en passant within this area.

In the present material, when WGA-HRP injections did not spread dorsal to the pars compacta, only two or three labeled perikarya were found in the ipsilateral lateral hypothalamus and these were at levels considerably more rostral than those on the contralateral side (Fig. 2D).
More dorsally placed injections, including an area just dorsal to the substantia nigra pars compacta and the medial lemniscus, labeled a larger number of these anterior hypothalamic neurons.
It should be emphasized that the contralateral and ipsilateral hypothalamic areas projecting to the substantia nigra are anatomically distinct.
Connections of the peribrachialpedunculopontine area with the substantia nigra

The present data suggest that while the substantia nigra receives afferents from the peribrachial-pedunculopontine area bilaterally, it in turn projects only to the ipsilateral peribrachial-pedunculopontine nucleus.

This semireciprocal system has been reported previously in the cat (Graybiel, '78; Moon-Edley and Graybiel, '80; Nomura et al., '80) and our data confirm the demonstration of an efferent connection to the ipsilateral pedunculopontine nucleus in the rat (Beckstead et al., '79).

The observation that peribrachial-pedunculopontine efferents to the subthalamic nucleus course through the substantia nigra (Moon-Edley and Graybiel, '80; Nomura et al., '80) somewhat compromises the conclusion that peribrachial-pedunculopontine efferents terminate within the substantia nigra, as has been suggested by this and previous studies.
The definitive demonstration of terminal labeling of peribrachial-pedunculopontine efferents within the substantia nigra awaits electron microscopic analysis.
The peribrachial-pedunculopontine area is particularly well connected with other components of the extrapyramidal system.

It receives afferents from the substantia nigra pak reticulata, from the ipsilateral and possibly contralateral entopeduncular nucleus (Nauta, '79; MoonEdley and Graybiel, 'BO), and from the ipsilateral and contralateral hypothalamus (Tohyama et al., '78; Moon-Edley and Graybiel, '80).

Efferent projections of the peribrachialpedunculopontine nucleus include the substantia nigra, subthalamic nucleus, and hypothalamus, and all of these appear to be bilateral (Tohyama et al., '78; Moon-Edley and Graybiel, '80).
These pathways provide a number of potential circuits that could mediate the interdependent control of activity in the right and left substantia nigra.
The most obvious is the direct input from the substantia nigra pars reticulata to the ipsilateral peribrachial-pedunculopontine area, which in turn projects bilaterally to the substantia nigra.

Another is suggested by the bilateral projection of the peribrachial-pedunculopontine nucleus onto the subthalamic nuclei, each of which projects to the ipsilateral substantia nigra and to the globus pallidus (Nauta and Cole, '79; Van der Kooy and Hattori, '80).
Nigrotectal connections
Using electrophysiological techniques, Deniau et al. ('77) obtained evidence for a crossed nigrotectal projection in the rat.

Anatomical techniques have been used to demonstrate bilateral innervation of the superior colliculus by nigral efferents in the cat and monkey (Hopkins and Niesen, '76; Rinvik et al., '76; Beckstead et al., '81).

However, previous HRP injections into the rat superior colliculus have been reported to result in the labeling of only a few (one or two) neurons in the contralateral substantia nigra pars reticulata (Beckstead et al., '81).
The present data, using complementary WGA-HRP injections into the superior colliculus and substantia nigra, indicate that the nigrotectal projection is bilateral in the rat.

The innervation of the contralateral superior colliculus appears to be less extensive than the ipsilateral innervation, in terms of both its distribution and the number of neurons contributing to the pathway.

However, the present observation of over 200 labeled neurons in the contralateral substantia nigra pars reticulata after superior colliculus WGAHRP injections suggests that this crossed pathway is much more extensive than previously suspected.

The distribution of the crossed pathway primarily into the lateral and deep layers of the superior colliculus probably accounts for the failure of previous investigations, using more superficial and caudal injections, to label this pathway more completely.
The suggestion of a topographic organization of the nigrotectal pathway is noteworthy.
Neurons located in the dorsal substantia nigra pars reticulata project to the rostral superior colliculus and more ventrally located nigral neurons project to the caudal superior colliculus.

For the most part previous studies have identified only ventrally located nigrotectal neurons (Faull and Mehler, '78; Beckstead et al., '81), consistent with the fact that only caudal injections of retrograde tracers were employed.
A mediolateral topography for this pathway has also been suggested (Steindler and Deniau, '80).
The superficial collicular layers receive primarily retinal and visual cortical input and project to primary visual areas of the thalamus and midbrain.
On the other hand, the intermediate and deep collicular layers are interconnected with nonvisual sensory and motor parts of the brain.

These layers receive, in addition to nigral efferents, nonvisual sensory input from the dorsal column nuclei (Lund and Webster, '67; Antonetty and Webster, '75), trigeminal nuclei (Smith, '73; Killackey and Erzurumlu, %1), and somatosensory cortex (Wise and Jones, '77), motor input from the cerebellum (Faull and Carman, '78) and frontal cortical eye fields (Leichnetz et al., '81), and provide ascending projections to the thalamic nuclei interconnected with the frontal cortex and basal ganglia (Herkenham, '79; Harting et al., '80), and descending projections to the spinal cord, brainstem motor nuclei, and reticular formation (Holcombe and Hall, '81 a,b).

Ascending crossed cerebellofugal projections innervate the lateral intermediate and deep tectal layers as well as thalamic nuclei including the parafascicular, ventromedial, and paralamellar mediodorsal nuclei (Faull and Carman, '78).
As demonstrated in the present study, the paralamellar mediodorsal nucleus receives a topographically ordered input, to some extent bilateral, from the intermediate and deep tectal layers.
These layers provide inputs to the ventromedial and parafascicular nuclei as well (Herkenham, '79; Harting et al., '80).

The association of these pathways, together with the thalamocortical and thalamostriatal pathways discussed below, with the substantia nigra, provide possible substrates for sensorimotor integration (Fig.

Neurons in the intermediate layers provide crossed afferents to the paramedian reticular formation while those in the deep layer innervate primarily the ipsilateral lateral reticular nucleus (Holcombe and Hall, '81a,b).
As noted above, it appeared that ipsilateral nigrotectal fibers terminated more superficially in the intermediate layers while the crossed pathway terminated primarily in the deep layer (Fig. 11).

Similarly, superior colliculus neurons projecting to the ipsilateral mediodorsal thalamic nucleus were most frequently located superficial to those providing crossed mediodorsal thalamic input (Fig. 10).
Further elaboration of this organization awaits a more detailed analysis.

The nonhomogeneous distribution of ipsilateral nigrotectal fibers and terminals observed presently and in previous studies (Graybiel, '78; Beckstead et al., '79) is similar to that of the trigeminotectal and somatosensory corticotectal afferents (Wise and Jones, '77; Killackey and Erzurumlu, '81).

Killackey and Erzurumlu ('81) have pointed out that the stratum album intermediale, the layer through which afferents distribute into the intermediate layers of the tectum, is laced with fascicular bunches of corticotectal fibers so that terminal labeling within this layer, while giving the appearance of nonhomogeneity, may in fact, with respect to the neuropil, be distributed evenly.

In this context it is significant that in contrast to the ipsilateral nigrotectal pathway which distributed into the stratum album intermediale, with distinctive pufflike labeling, and stratum griseum intermediale, the contralateral nigrotectal terminal distribution primarily into the stratum griseum profundum was homogeneous.
Nigrothalamic connections
The present data revealed for the first time a nigral efferent pathway to the lateral dorsal thalamic nucleus.
Evidence for this pathway was obtained both with injections of WGA-HRP into the substantia nigra and into the lateral dorsal thalamic nucleus.

The lateral dorsal nucleus has been implicated in a system linking sensory areas, the pretectal nuclei, with limbic cortices including the cingulate, retrosplenial, and presubicular areas (Ryska and Heger, '79; Robertson et al., '80).
Nigral input to this nucleus may convey not only additional sensory but also motor information to this circuit.

Previous studies have demonstrated the existence of nigral inputs to the ipsilateral parafascicular, ventromedial, and both the ipsilateral and contralateral paralamellar mediodorsal thalamic nuclei (Faull and Carman, '68; Carpenter and Peter, '72; Carpenter et al., '76; Clavier et al., '76; Faull and Mehler, '78; Beckstead et al., '79; Herkenham, '79; Bentivoglio et al., '79).

The present data confirm and extend these reports with the demonstration of a minor nigral afferent connection from the ipsilateral parafascicular thalamic nucleus and a bilateral nigral projection to the ventromedial thalamic nucleus.

Pritzel and Huston ('80) have reported that unilateral lesions of the substantia nigra induce the contralateral substantia nigra to innervate the ventromedial nucleus of the thalamus ipsilateral to the lesion.

However, the present findings and those of Herkenham ('79), who reported an occasional labeled neuron in the contralateral substantia nigra aRer HRP injections into the ventromedial nucleus of the thalamus, point to a crossed input, albeit minor, to the ventromedial nucleus from the substantia nigra in the intact animal.
Thus the report of an induction of this crossed system after unilateral nigral lesions seems likely due to an expansion (sprouting) of an existing crossed projection.

The connections of the thalamic nuclei receiving nigral input demonstrate not only possible pathways through which activity in the right and left substantia nigra may be linked, but also the complexity of the neuronal circuits which may influence and be influenced by nigral efferent activity.

These circuits include ascending projections to the striatal and cortical regions that provide descending input to the substantia nigra and inputs to thalamic nuclei from the superior colliculus and peribrachial-pedunculopontine areas that receive nigral input (Fig. 15).
Nigrothalamocortical connections

Although not yet demonstrated by electron microscopic analysis, studies employing fiber degeneration staining (Leonard, '69) and autoradiographic (Beckstead, '79) techniques have revealed a frontocorticonigral pathway.

The present data conform with previous studies suggesting that cortical input to the substantia nigra originates from the medial and lateral precentral cortices and from the AId prefrontal cortex (Bunney and Aghajanian, '76).
There is an intimate relationship between these cortical areas and those thalamic nuclei that receive input from the substantia nigra.

The medial precentral cortex is reciprocally connected with that portion of the mediodorsal thalamic nucleus, the paralamellar, that receives nigral efferents (Leonard, '69; Krettek and Price, '77; Beckstead, '79).

The precentral motor cortex of the monkey, corresponding to the lateral precentral cortex of the rat, has also been reported to project to the paralamellar portion of the mediodorsal nucleus (Akert et al., '79).
The present data suggest a similar pathway in the rat, but more extensive investigations are needed to confirm this.
The mediodorsal nucleus projection onto the AId prefrontal cortex overlaps with the medial aspect of the paralamellar segment which is innervated by the substantia nigra (Gerfen and Clavier, '79).
The present study suggests that the AId prefrontal cortex projects to the more rostral and lateral parts of the paralamellar mediodorsal nucleus as well.
All of the pathways discussed above, with the notable exception of the corticonigral pathway, are to some extent bilateral.
In the rat, the ventromedial thalamic nucleus projects widely to layer I of most of the neocortex (Krettek and Price, '77; Herkenham, '79, '80).
The AId prefrontal and the lateral precentral cortex receive additional input to layers I11 and V.
These cortical regions, in addition to providing nigral afferents, also project back to the ventromedial thalamic nucleus.

Like nigral efferents to the mediodorsal nucleus, nigral input to the ventromedial thalamic nucleus, by virtue of its crossed nature, provides potential for the multisynaptic connection between one substantia nigra and its contralateral counterpart.
A similar feedback loop to the substantia nigra, although primarily an ipsilateral system, is provided by nigral input to the parafascicular thalamic nucleus.
Thalamostriatal and corticostriatonigral pathways
Each thalamic nuclear region receiving nigral efferents has been reported to project to the ipsilateral striatum.

While striatal afferents originating in the mediodorsal and ventromedial thalamic nuclei are minor (Krettek and Price, '77; Herkenham, '791, the parafascicular nucleus provides a massive input to the striatum (Jones and Leavitt, '74).
The mosaic distribution of the parafascicular projection to the striatum reported by Herkenham and Pert ('81) was confirmed in the present study (Fig. 8D).
These projections provide, via the striatonigral pathway, an alternate feedback loop to the substantia nigra.
The striatum also receives a significant input from the intralaminar nucleus but to date there is no clear evidence that this nucleus receives a nigral input (Carpenter and Peter, '72).
The cortical areas that project to the nigra and receive mediodorsal, ventromedial, or parafascicular thalamic input also project to the striatum (Beckstead, '79).
To some extent these are bilateral pathways with fibers crossing in the corpus callosum.

The work of Nieoullon et al. ('78) suggests that these pathways, together with crossed corticocortical connections, may provide a neuronal substrate linking activity in the two nigrostriatal DA systems.

They reported that unilateral activation of the motor cortex resulted in activation of both nigrostriatal pathways and that transection of the rostral part of the corpus callosum abolished the contralateral but not the ipsilateral response.
Connections between the nigrotectal and nigrothalamic pathways
Collateralization of nigral efferents.
Previous reports have suggested that collaterals of a large number of nigrothalamic neurons project to the ipsilateral tectum (Bentivoglio et al., '79; Steindler and Deniau, '80).
Preliminary data (Gerfen and Staines, unpublished observations) suggest that some of the crossed nigrotectal fibers are collaterals of axons that provide ipsilateral nigrotectal input.

Whether single neurons within the substantia nigra pars reticulata have axons with collaterals not only to the tectum and ventromedial thalamic nucleus, but additional collaterals to the mediodorsal, parafascicular, and the contralateral counterparts of each of these nuclei remains to be demonstrated.
Topography of nigral efferents.
Herkenham ('79) reported an organization of nigral connections with the ventromedial nucleus in which mediolateral and dorsoventral topography is preserved.
There was no apparent rostrocaudal axis to this organization.
The present data suggest a topographical organization of nigromediodorsal and nigrotectal pathways as well.

Medial and ventral segments of thepars reticulata appear to project to the medial paralamellar mediodorsal nucleus while dorsal and lateral segments of the pars reticulata project to its lateral part.

Neurons projecting to the rostral tectum originate in the rostrodorsal aspect of the substantia nigra pars reticulata while rostroventral neurons within the pars reticulata project to the caudal superior colliculus.
A mediolateral nigrotectal topography has been reported previously (Steindler and Deniau, '80).
In the present study a similar mediolateral topography was apparent in the projection of the tectum onto the mediodorsal nucleus.

Superior colliculus neurons formed a continuum within which medial and lateral tectal neurons projected to the medial and lateral portions, respectively, of the paralamellar division of the mediodorsal nucleus.

Anterograde transport of WGA-HRP following tectal injections labeled terminals not only in the paralamellar mediodorsal nucleus but also confirmed previous reports of tectal input to the ventromedial and parafascicular thalamic nuclei (Ahlenius, '78; Herkenham, '79).
These projections are to some extent bilateral.
As discussed above, each of these thalamic nuclei have connections with cortical regions providing nigral afferents.

Of note is the suggestion of a topographic organization, not only in the nigrotectal, nigrothalamic, and tectothalamic pathways discussed above, but of a topographic organization that is maintained between the thalamocortical and the corticonigral pathways as well.
Functional considerations
The connections of the substantia nigra with the ascending tectothalamocortical and striatal pathways are schematized in Figure 15.
There is an emerging view that these pathways may have a functional role in sensory attentiveness.

Physiological investigations have suggested that both the frontal cortical eye fields and the stratum griseum of the superior colliculus are responsive to somatosensory and auditory stimuli (Cynader and Berman, '72; Gordon, '73; Stein et al., '76) and function in the regulation of saccadic eye movements (Bizzi, '68; Koerner, '72; Wurtz and Goldberg, '72).

Neuronal activity in the substantia nigra has been reported to be altered by stimulation of visual or motor cortices (Nieoullon et al., '78) and by the presentation of a variety of peripheral stimuli (Nieoullon et al., '77a,b; Chiodo et al., '79).

Thus, physiological evidence has suggested that these neuronal systems are involved in both sensory and motor function while lesion studies are suggestive of a role for these pathways in the integration of these functions.

Lesions of the nigrostriatal DA system have been reported to produce contralateral neglect of visual or somesthetic stimuli and a facilitation of ipsilateral visual responsiveness (Marshall, '78; Feeney and Wier, '79).
Similar behavioral effects are produced by collicular ablations (Marshall, '78; Sprague et al., '73).
This report brings together and expands upon what can now be seen as the very complex anatomy of the substantia nigra.
A summary of the efferent and afferent connections of the substantia nigra is provided in Figure 14.
The role played by each of these connections in the observed nigral interplay awaits further study.
